mods.abstract: Menawa (meaning The Great Warrior) was chief of the Oakfuskee Creek towns lying on the Tallapoosa River in Alabama. He was widely known as a talented and brutal warrior. A determined opponent of both Creek Chief William MacIntosh and MacIntosh's 1825 Treaty of Indian Springs (which ceded all Creek land in Georgia to the Federal Government), Menawa took part in the 1826 delegation to Washington, DC designed to repudiate the treaty. Although the group failed to have the treaty revoked, Menawa was instrumental in having a provision inserted allowing the Creek to obtain legal patents for their land. He, along with Opothle Yoholo, later fought alongside American troops against the Seminole in Alabama. This print was taken from a portrait painted by Charles Bird King in 1826, when Menawa was said to be about sixty years old. The original has since been destroyed by fire.
